questions.question: 1. A signal has a mean of 5 and a variance that fluctuates over time. Can this signal be considered wide-sense stationary (WSS)?

answers.a: Yes, if the autocorrelation depends only on the time difference.
answers.b: No, because the variance is not constant.
answers.c: Yes, if the mean and variance are time-invariant on average.
answers.d: No, because WSS requires both mean and variance to be constant.

explanations.a: WSS also requires constant mean and variance.
explanations.c: Time-invariance on average is not sufficient for WSS.
explanations.d: WSS requires both mean and variance to remain constant over time.

questions.question: 2. An LTI system has an impulse response that is zero for all values of time greater than a certain constant. What does this imply about the system?

answers.a: The system is time-invariant but not necessarily causal.
answers.b: The system is causal and has finite memory.

explanations.a: Time-invariance does not depend on the impulse response being finite.
explanations.b: Finite impulse response implies causality and finite memory.
explanations.c: Stability is determined by bounded input and output, not impulse response length.
explanations.d: Invertibility is unrelated to finite impulse response.

questions.question: 3. What does it mean if the transfer function of a system has poles outside the unit circle in the z-domain?

explanations.a: Poles outside the unit circle indicate instability.
explanations.b: Causality is unrelated to pole location.
explanations.c: Time-variance is unrelated to pole location.
explanations.d: Stability, not WSS, is determined by pole location.

questions.question: 4. How does the inclusion of a moving average (MA) term in an ARMA model affect its frequency response?

answers.a: It sharpens the peak of the response.
answers.b: It smoothens the response by adding zeros.
answers.c: It introduces poles into the system.
answers.d: It does not affect the frequency response.

explanations.a: MA terms generally smoothen the response, not sharpen it.
explanations.b: MA terms add zeros, smoothening the overall response.
explanations.c: Poles are introduced by the AR term, not the MA term.
explanations.d: MA terms significantly affect the frequency response.

questions.question: 5. What is the key difference between a WSS process and a strict-sense stationary (SSS) process?

answers.a: WSS assumes higher-order moments are time-invariant.
answers.b: SSS requires constant mean and variance, while WSS does not.
answers.c: SSS requires invariance of all moments, while WSS considers only second-order moments.
answers.d: There is no difference; they are equivalent.

explanations.a: Higher-order moments are not considered in WSS.
explanations.b: WSS also requires constant mean and variance.
explanations.c: SSS is stricter, requiring invariance of all moments.
explanations.d: WSS and SSS are not equivalent.

questions.question: 6. If a WSS signal passes through an LTI system, what will be the nature of the output signal?

answers.a: The output signal will always be wide-sense stationary.
answers.b: The output signal will be non-stationary.
answers.c: The output signal will have the same autocorrelation as the input.
answers.d: The output signal will be stationary only if the system is causal.

explanations.a: An LTI system preserves WSS properties.
explanations.b: Non-stationarity does not result from LTI systems.
explanations.c: The autocorrelation of the output depends on the system's impulse response.
explanations.d: Causality is unrelated to preserving stationarity.

questions.question: 7. In an ARMA(1,1) model, what happens when the pole and zero are very close to each other in the z-domain?

answers.c: The system's response becomes heavily damped.
answers.d: The pole-zero cancellation occurs, simplifying the system.

explanations.a: Oscillatory behavior depends on pole location, not proximity to zeros.
explanations.b: Instability is not caused by pole-zero proximity.
explanations.c: Close pole-zero pairs dampen the response.
explanations.d: Pole-zero cancellation can simplify the system.

questions.question: 8. If an AR(2) process has roots that lie on the unit circle, what can be said about the process?

answers.a: The process is stable and stationary.
answers.b: The process is marginally stable but not stationary.
answers.c: The process is unstable and stationary.
answers.d: The process is neither stable nor stationary.

explanations.a: Roots on the unit circle indicate marginal stability, not full stability.
explanations.b: Marginal stability occurs with roots on the unit circle, but stationarity is lost.
explanations.c: Instability is not associated with unit-circle roots.
explanations.d: Marginal stability applies here, not full instability.

questions.question: 9. How does the inclusion of a high-order AR term in an ARMA model influence its autocorrelation properties?

answers.a: It shortens the decay rate of the autocorrelation.
answers.b: It extends the memory of the process.
answers.c: It eliminates oscillatory behavior in the autocorrelation.
answers.d: It has no effect on the autocorrelation.

explanations.a: Higher-order AR terms extend the memory, not shorten it.
explanations.b: Higher-order AR terms increase the decay length of autocorrelation.
explanations.c: Oscillatory behavior depends on pole locations, not order.
explanations.d: Autocorrelation is directly influenced by AR terms.

questions.question: 10. What is the effect of adding a long-memory MA term to an ARMA model in the frequency domain?

answers.a: It increases the bandwidth of the process.
answers.b: It adds sharp resonances at specific frequencies.

explanations.a: Bandwidth is not directly affected by MA terms.
explanations.b: Resonances are typically introduced by poles, not zeros.
explanations.c: Long-memory MA terms smoothen or suppress high frequencies.
explanations.d: Low-frequency enhancement depends on specific placements of zeros.
